feed.title: The Developers‚Äô Bakery
feed.subtitle: A podcast about Developer Tools and productivity, freshly baked to you by Nicola Corti.

entry.title: #15 - Deep-clean with Sebastiano Poggi
entry.content:
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚ò¢Ô∏è‚ò¢Ô∏è When Gradle or the IDE let you down, just --nuke all them caches ‚ò¢Ô∏è‚ò¢Ô∏è‚ò¢Ô∏è

Today‚Äôs project is basically a script: deep-clean.

This script is the last resort to unblock yourself when your Android/JVM/Gradle builds are damn broken. deep-clean will take care of cleaning up your build caches. If you‚Äôre really stuck, you should also look into the --nuke option to purge every possible cache and start from a clean environment.

Its author, Sebastiano Poggi, is on stage to tell us the story behind it.

As a bonus, we also talk a bit about Seb‚Äôs new journey with Twitch: CodeWithTheItalians üçï.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00.19 Intro
  • 01.05 Episode Start
  • 01.36 Seb‚Äôs Introduction

  • 08.31 deep-clean as a last resort
  • 11.25 From a script to a popular project
  • 13.30 Kotlin as a scripting language

  • 18.05 Community contributions
  • 19.59 deep-clean on Brew?

entry.title: #14 - Anvil with Ralf Wondratschek
entry.content:
‚ÄúWhen all you have is an anvil, every problem looks like a hammer.‚Äù - Abraham Maslow

So it starts the Anvil üî® README.

Anvil is a plugin to make your dependency injection with Dagger 2 easier.

We have the pleasure to host Ralf Wondratschek, Mobile Engineer @ Square. He‚Äôs going to tell us how Anvil can make your life with Dagger 2 easier and faster.

Did you know that this project was originally called Hephaestus? Make sure to don‚Äôt miss this episode if you want to learn this and other stories behind this project.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00.19 Intro
  • 01.05 Episode Start
  • 01.31 Ralf‚Äôs Introduction
  • 02.21 What is Anvil?
  • 02.51 What is Dagger?
  • 05.20 Ralf‚Äôs opinion on Dependency Injection
  • 07.27 Any bad experiences with Dagger?
  • 08.41 What problem is Anvil solving?
  • 14.03 Is Anvil useful if I have only one Android project?
  • 15.47 What‚Äôs the story of Anvil?
  • 17.56 Anvil Internals
  • 22.12 How stable is Anvil?

entry.title: #13 - Apollo GraphQL with Martin Bonnin
entry.content:
Today we have on stage Martin Bonnin, Android Engineer at Apollo GraphQL üöÄ.

Martin has the amazing opportunity to work full time for an open-source project: Apollo Android, probably the most popular GraphQL client for Android.

In this episode Martin will tell us his experience with GraphQL, how he got involved with Apollo and how it is to work full time on a oss project.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

  • 01.07 Episode Start
  • 01.38 Martin‚Äôs Introduction

  • 12.50 What is offered by Apollo?
  • 15.07 What is Apollo Android?

  • 23.19 The Normalized Cache

  • 36.16 What‚Äôs next in 3.0?

  • 41.17 Further readings
  • 42.22 Where to find Martin online?

entry.title: #12 - refreshVersions with Louis CAD
entry.content:
Have you ever ventured inside the dependency hell üòà? Louis CAD has for sure. Today we‚Äôre talking about refreshVersions, a Gradle plugin to help you keep your third-party dependencies up to date.

The killer feature of refreshVersions is the possibility to see all the available versions as comments in your versions file. They‚Äôre just a ‚áß + down keystroke away to update:

Louis will also tell us his personal experience with pair programming in the open-source ecosystem. If you‚Äôre looking for a peer to get into open-source, make sure you send Louis a message!

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00.25 Intro
  • 01.11 Episode Start
  • 01.41 Louis‚Äô Introduction
  • 02.56 What is refreshVersion?
  • 04.56 The Dependency Hell problem
  • 05.54 API breaking changes
  • 06.35 The cost of bumping dependencies
  • 07.25 Dependency bundles and versions alignment
  • 09.27 The history of this project
  • 13.18 How the find newer versions?
  • 15.05 A new dependency notation
  • 16.46 How to use refreshVersions?
  • 19.14 New versions as comments
  • 19.51 Java Properties vs JSON/YAML
  • 22.24 refreshVersions vs Gradle Version Catalog
  • 26.33 refreshVersions vs Dependabot
  • 29.42 How to contribute to refreshVersions?
  • 32.13 Pair programming in open source
  • 35.36 Have you ever had bad experiences with pair programming?
  • 37.59 Tools for pair programming
  • 39.31 How to pair program with Louis?
  • 42.02 What‚Äôs next for refreshVersions?
  • 43.38 Where to find Louis online?

entry.title: #11 - MoshiX and KSP with Zac Sweers

link.title: #11 - MoshiX and KSP with Zac Sweers

entry.content:
It‚Äôs time to talk about meta-programming, annotation processors and compiler plugins üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Today we have Zac Sweers on stage, Mobile Engineer @ Slack and maintainer of Moshi, a popular Json library.

Zac is the author of MoshiX, a set of extensions for Moshi. Between those, one that caught my attention was moshi-ksp. KSP (Kotlin Symbol Processing API) is set to revolutionize the landscape of annotations processors in Kotlin. Join us on this deep dive on code generation and more.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

entry.title: #10 - Press with Saket Narayan
entry.content:
üéÇ We‚Äôre happy to celebrate our 10th episode! üéÇ

And today we have on stage, Saket Narayan, Android Engineer at Square. Saket is an master of Android UI and Custom Views and today is on stage to talk to us about Press.

Press is a beautiful App for taking notes as markdown. The app is completely open source and is a great inspiration for minimal yet elegant UI.

Moreover, Press is developed with Kotlin Multiplatform. This project is a great example of how you can share Kotlin code between Android, iOS and MacOS. Make sure to don‚Äôt miss it.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

  • 08:37 How much code where you able to share?

entry.title: #09 - JaCoCo with Evgeny Mandrikov
entry.content:
This episode is going to be all about testing and code coverage üß™ as we have Evgeny Mandrikov on stage!

He‚Äôs going to tell use the story behind JaCoCo, aka Java Code Coverage, one the most popular code coverage library for Java, Kotlin and the JVM.

If you‚Äôre curious to learn how a code coverage tool works internally, make sure to don‚Äôt miss this episode.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

entry.title: #08 - Tuist with Pedro Pi√±era Buend√≠a
entry.content:
You don‚Äôt need a tooling team

That‚Äôs Tuist motto, and if you‚Äôre an iOS Developer üçé you really don‚Äôt want to miss it.

Today we have Pedro Pi√±era Buend√≠a on stage. He‚Äôs the author and maintainer of Tuist, a tool to help you maintain and generate your XCode Projects. Pedro will tell us about the history of this tool and how it plays with monorepo and dependency management.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

entry.title: #07 - VelocityX and Flutter with Pawan Kumar

link.title: #07 - VelocityX and Flutter with Pawan Kumar

entry.content:
Do you know Flutter üíô ? I bet you do, if you‚Äôre into mobile development. Today, we have Pawan Kumar on stage, he‚Äôs a Flutter & Dart GDE and he is on stage to advocate for cross-platform development.

Pawan is the author of VelocityX, a framework that will make your UI development experience even faster. He will tell us more about this framework, how it started and what the inspiration came from.

Also, make sure to don‚Äôt miss the bonus question Kotlin vs Dart (39:50) ‚ÅâÔ∏è

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

entry.title: #06 - Koin with Arnaud Giuliani
entry.content:
In this episode, we talk about Dependency Injection üó°. We have Arnaud Giuliani on stage, Kotlin GDE and author of Koin, a popular dependency injection framework for Kotlin.

Koin works well for Android projects, but it can be used also in backend projects and the Multiplatform support is just behind the corner.

Arnaud will tell us the story of this framework: how it started, how it grew and how its feature will look like.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥
